The enclosure to my Printed Letter No.c/117 of the 24th of January 1945 and paragraphs 21(i), 183, and 226 of my Intelligence Summaries for 1944 dealt with this M excellent fuel'. The coke is of very high calorific value and burns with a clear flame but has the disadvantage of eventually destroying the iron basket or grate which is used as a con tainer. It is sold by the Bahrain petroleum Company at Rs.10/ a ton with an additional charge of Re.l/- each bag which is used returnable on the return of the bag. A further charge of Ps. 10/- a ton is levied to cover the cost of the transport of the coke to Manama. I am sending a bag of coke as a free-will offering. If you desire any further information I feel sure both Rogers and Hadow will be able to help for both of them have first-hand knowledge of the product. Yours sincerely, G* Dauheny, Esq., O.B.E., Secretary to the Hobble the Political Resident in the Persian Gulf Bushire.e 0)1^ No. 4161 - 13/3. Memorandum Reference your telegram No.A/1684 dated the 14th December, 1945. 2. (a) Jack for Political Resident's car. A new one is not obtainable locally but I am trying to get a second hand one and if available will send it by the next mail. (b) Two dozens Chinese lanterns. Not available in Bahrain. (c) Six account books. I do not know what size you require but am sending herewith two registers, costing Rs.30/- each. No larger size is available and the cost of smaller ones is also exhorbitant. (d) Cartridges. According to Political Resident's instructions only 1000 twelve bore cartridges (500 of No.4 and 500 of No.6) are sent herewith. (e & f) V.I.R. wire and eyelets. They are sent herewith. (g) Thirty pounds white flour. The only white flour available locally is old, weevily and costs about Hi annas per pound, and I am not sending any. I got 100 lbs. of white flour for the Political Resident. for Political Agent, Bahrain c6. The State Medical Officer, Bahrain* Meiaorandiim. ^ As the present arrangement for getting Penicillin from Tehran for the Residency Hospital, Bushire, has proved most unsatis factory and irregular, the Hon’ble the Political Resident in the Persian Gulf desires me to ask you kindly to include in your indent on London, an additional 500,000 units of Penicillin fort nightly to meet the requirements of the Residency Hospital. 2. MEDICAL DEPARTMENT. To Bahrain Government Hospital May 20th: 1946* H.B.M’s Political Agent, Bahrain. MEMO : Pen icillin - T he Residency Hospital y Bushire • With reference to your memo: dated 18.5*46, please convey to The Hon’ble The Political Resident in the Persian Gulf my willing co-operation to fall in with his wishes to supply The Residency Hospital with 1,000 000 units (10 vials) Pencillin monthly from my monthly consignments from London if the authorities will augment my supplies proportionately. 2. As soon as each consignment arrives I will then for- -ward 10 vials to the Q.M.O. Bahrain to keep refrigerated pending shipment to Bushire. 5* The cost is approximately £ 0. 10. 0. per vial of 100 000 units, i.e. i 5. per month including air freight- -age. I will however forward an exact statement of accounts to the Agency at the end of each current year. 4. Regarding increasing my present indent to meet the needs of Bushire, will you very kindly order the necessary extra om my behalf,as I have no powers to procure this from w£4fe India Office or the other London authorities direct. If Mr F.A*K. Harrison External Dept: India Office be approached by the Political Dept: asking him to arrange for a further 10 vials (Total 1 million units) Penicillin to be added to my monthly indent,earmarked for The Residency,Bushire, there should be no difficulty in procuring it./ *11 GOVERNMENT OF BAHRAIN. MEDICAL DEPARTMENT. 2 . 5* The procedure whereby Pencillin was granted by the India Office to the Bahrain Government in October 1945 was highly involved, and its monthly journey out from the manufacturers to this dept: is still very indirect,although it arrives quickly enough, unrefrigerated, to be potent and effective. India Office first authorised Pencillin as being essential for Bahrain,and they requested The Director of Medical Supplies, Ministry of Supply^,to supply. The Pencillin Production Control Dept: were in turn deputed to arrange. It is this dept; who forwards the monthly consignments to India Office for forwarding by air freightage to the Agency,Bahrain, for eventual forwarding to the Bahrain Govt: Medical Dept; Its monthly journey from door to door is therefore:- Messers: Boots,manufacturers to Pencillin Production Control Dept: to India Office to B*0*A*C. to The Agency,Bahrain to Bahrain Govt: Medical Dept: I wish this arrangement could be shortcircuited. It would certainly help and save 24 hours if you would kindly authorise B«0*A*Co Bahrain to telephone me its arrival so I can instantly clear it and refrigerate it,without it passing through your office. 6. I gather that Pencillin is becoming increasingly plentiful in England,so I anticipate that this present arrangement will not be in force for more than a year,after which we will be able to procure the drug direct from the manufacturers in any quantity. 20.5.46 State Medical Officer, Bahrain.GTC Secretary to the Political Resident,Busbire. location.physicalLocation: British Library: India Office Records and Private Papers

titleInfo.title: ‘File 16/32-A Purchases on behalf of Bushire Residency’

physicalDescription.extent: The file’s contents are arranged in approximate chronological order, from the earliest item at the front to the latest at the end. The file notes at the end of the file (ff 156-171) mirror the chronological arrangement.

Foliation: The foliation sequence commences at the front cover with 1 and terminates at the inside back cover with 172; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio. An additional foliation sequence is present in parallel between ff 2-53; these numbers are also written in pencil, but are not circled.

mods.abstract: Correspondence and other papers, exchanged between staff at the Political Agency in Bahrain and others, including the British Residency and Consulate in Bushire and the Government of Bahrain, relating to the order or exchange of goods from suppliers, merchants and colleagues, with shipping arrangements frequently made with the Bahrain shipping agent Gray, Mackenzie & Company Limited. Goods discussed include:Electrolux refrigerators, ordered through the Bahrain merchant Yousuf Abdul Rahman Fakhroo, and including correspondence for the delivery of one refrigerator to H Borovitz of the Etimadeyah Spinning and Weaving Company in Bushire;medical supplies, including quinine, and a request from the Chief Medical Officer for the Government of Bahrain for Penicillin, with correspondence following on arrangements for the quick delivery of Penicillin to Bahrain;other miscellaneous items including coke, washing soda, vegetable ghee, electrical wiring, coir matting, car batteries, and stamps.A small number of papers in the file are in Arabic.

name.namePart: Gray, Mackenzie and Company Limited, shipping agents
